instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.I2C_BKLT_SDA: What is I2C_BKLT_SDA? I2C_BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Hi ive got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight, board has no liquid damge, 5v on screen enable and have pic , 12v on backlight so its not boosting, its 100% working screen, at <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> pins 17 and 18 i get 5v,, <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> feedback resistors measure fine also checked connection to the lcd connector and fine, changed <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> three times just incase i had bad chips but still get no boosting, backlight fet driver resistor also measured fine and changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> just out of desperation :-)  now im going round in circles and must be missing the obvious so if anyone can shed some light i would be more than greatfull

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> present??

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: yes got 5v there

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Diode mode on <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL>???

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Also try another display assambly, remember should 2015!!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: 0.527  <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> , 0.549 <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: checked display assy with another board and alls fine

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: diode readings are with the screen connected

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Remove display and measure again...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> 1.821 ,  <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>  0.575

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> is to high!! <RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR> value??? this could be a bad <RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR>, broken trace or dead <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> 1.821, I would say there is a bad trace or dead backlight IC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: ok so yes the trace is bad , ive run a wire from pin 1 <RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR> to pin 2 <RESISTOR>R7753</RESISTOR> then up to pin 2 <CAPACITOR>C8358</CAPACITOR> and test point next to it, then had to go across to pin 4 of screen connector now at each point i get the same reading of 0.454 but still no boosting on the backlight, done pram reset just incase

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: No boost is something else than no backlight. What is the voltage on backlight output pin?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Hi Duke im getting 12.2v pin 1 of j8300

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: That is good then there is communication with the LCD/driver chip. <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: arh did have ealier now reading 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: ok ive run a wire from <RESISTOR>R8309</RESISTOR> which has <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> down to <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> , <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> is reading fine but still no backlight :-(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Check again for <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> at U770 to make sure. Was there corrosion around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>? Did you do a PRAM reset? Known good LCD for 2015 model?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: yep <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> at U770 present  , as far as i can see no corrosion anywhere , did a pram reset and yes lcd works on another board

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: What is voltage now on the LCD connector? Still 12.2V? Tested LCD on another 4924 board? Check <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: yes voltage still 12.2v on lcd connector , 0v on <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> pin 8 of lcd connector and 0v everwhere else for that signal , is it pssible to run a wire from l8300 for the 5v or am i gonna blow the board

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: So there is no PWM signal. I have to ask again if you are sure this is a 2015 LCD assembly and if it was tested on a 2015 machine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: yes i used another customers board to check this screen and also my test screen and both were working , unless ive managed to blow both these screens but this board has now gone so i cant recheck the screens i have, i have rechecked the board and now im getting 1.47v at <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> pin 8 of lcd connector, still 12.2v at pin 1

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Do a diode mode reading on LCD connector pins 1-10 without LCD connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message:
without lcd connected the readings are:
pin1=0.519
pin2=ol
pin3=0.543
pin4=0.543
pin5=0.669
pin6=0.757
pin7=0.758
pin8=0.705
pin9=0.808
pin10=0.559

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: That looks ok. I have no idea besides still the LCD not being a 2015 model. What machine did you test it on?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: its was an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> serial number c02qjtcefvh3 which ive just looked up again and should be 2015

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Only suspects left would be <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> then.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight headache
threads.message: Duke thankyou for your patience you put me in the right direction with the broken trace on the <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> line which if i had done as i replied back to you with what i done ie pin 4 of the lcd then i would have saved myself hours of frustration, like a prize pratt i soldered it to pin 3 of the lcd connector, this week i have learnt alot about the backlight circuit and it reminded me why this site is worth every penny, thankyou and to aprendiz too :-)
